thread.title_full: NIck Davila in new role as Arizona Rattlers QBs coach

author: Richard Obert , azcentral sports
title: NIck Davila in new role as Arizona Rattlers QBs coach
text:
Nick Davila, six months after leading the Rattlers to a fifth ArenaBowl in six years as quarterback, is now the QB coach for the IFL Rattlers (Photo: David Wallace/azcentral sports) 
Nick Davila wears a black cap and holds a sheet of plays in his hand, as he stands next to the Rattlers offense during training camp in Maricopa.
It is a strange sight to see the player turned coach.
Just six months ago, Davila was leading the Rattlers into their fifth ArenaBowl since 2011 as the quarterback and was named the Arena Football League Most Valuable Player.
"I'm excited about this new step for me as a man," Davila said after the Rattlers' first practice this week as the newest member of the 10-team Indoor Football League. "I've been playing Arena Football for nine years. That's a long time to be playing Arena Football.
"It's been a blast. Now, I look forward to my life. I knew I was always going to get into coaching. I'm totally blessed I get to stay here in Arizona with a great organization, a great coach. I'm really fortunate to be here."
RELATED: Rattlers QB Thomas hits ground running 
This is a new world for Davila and the Rattlers, breaking off from the 30-year-old Arena Football League, where it was all about the offense and passing the ball.
Now, they're starting work in their first Indoor Football League season.
The IFL is made for the dual-threat quarterback, guys who can do as much damage with their legs as they can with their arm.
Davila, 31, was one of the last remaining pure drop-back passers in professional football.
Not wanting to unsettle his family in the Valley, Davila decided to stay with the Rattlers as their quarterbacks coach under head coach Kevin Guy.
Davila built one of the greatest resumes in AFL history. He ranks among the top 10 for career passing yards (32,612), career touchdown passes (766) and career completion percentage (67.4).
And he did that in only seven AFL seasons, all with the Rattlers. His first two seasons were spent with the Spokane Shock in af2.
"All of the knowledge that I've gained, I'm going to pass to them (three quarterbacks in camp)," Davila said. "It's their time now to shine. It's time for them to lead this organization."
Guy said Davila has embraced his new role. The playbook has changed.
There are more advantages for the defense in the IFL. But the offense also can do more things, such as send two players in motion before the ball is snapped.
"Everybody is in the same boat, but he's doing a great job," Guy said. "He's going to continue to do a good job."
Davila said he hasn't lost that itch to play.
"I think you're always going to have that itch, right?" he said. "When you're a competitor and a quarterback like I was, and I was fortunate to play for a great team, that's never going to go away.
"I understand that I've had a nice nine-year run. Now, it's my time for me to think about my family, my kids, be a father."
Davila would have had opportunities to play in the AFL, even with the league reduced to just five teams, including expansion Washington and Baltimore.
But all of the teams are in the east, and Davila is settled in the Valley with his wife taking on a new job.
"She's stable, and she's been waiting to do that," Davila said. "It's not fair to her if I pack up and leave her with three kids and a dog."
